Name: lian qian cao
Other: bian di jin qian 遍地金錢
jin qian han cao 金錢早草
chuan chuan qiang cao 穿穿牆草
jin qian bo he 金錢薄荷
shi ba que cao 十八缺草
shi fang lei gong gen 四方雷公根
ma ti jin gu cao 馬蹄筋骨草
dui ye jin qian cao 對葉金錢草

Geography: Mainly produced in Jiangsu and Zhejiang area.
Besides Northwestern part and Inner Mongolia, it is found in all parts of China.
Maladies Treated: Pediatric epilepsy.
Gan disease (infantile malnutrition).
Scrofulaceum (瘰疬).
Red eye: grind into juice and use as eye drop.
Swollen carbuncles and eczema: mix with salt and make into paste to apply externally.
Mumps (parotitis): use fresh herb, pound into paste and apply externally. [2]
Rheumatoid arthritis: smash lian qian cao; stir fry with wine until warm and apply externally. [3]
Medical Function: Antipyretic.
Antitussive.
Quenching thirst.
Hemostatic.
Diuretic.
Samples of Formulae:
For mumps (parotitis): use fresh Lian Qian Cao (Long tube ground ivy), pound into paste and apply externally. [2]
For rheumatoid arthritis: smash Lian Qian Cao (Long tube ground ivy), stir fry with wine until warm and apply externally. [3]
Contraindications: Not to take in cases of gangrene (陰疽), blood deficiency, and during pregnancy.
Research:
Cholagogue (promotes bile secretion): promotes bile cell bile secretion; bile in the liver and bile ducts increases; internal pressure rises; bile duct sphincter muscle relaxes, allowing bile to be discharged. [1]
Diuretic effect: decoction administered intragastrically to rats produced significant diuresis; with continuous application the diuretic effect gradually decreased. Anesthetized rabbits also showed obvious diuretic effect. (animal experiments) [1]
Dissolving stones effect: causes the urine to become acidic, so calculi that exist under alkaline conditions dissolve. [1]
Antibacterial test: extremely sensitive to Staphylococcus aureus; sensitive to Shigella sonnei; not sensitive to Escherichia coli, Pseudomonas aeruginosa, or Salmonella typhi. [1]
References: [1] 《zhong Hua Ben Cao 中華本草: 》

Medical Function: Effect of inhibiting Staphylococcus aureus

Cool the blood (涼血)

Dosage: Internal: decoction 6–10 g. Fresh root: 10–30 g. External application: appropriate amount.
Samples of Formulae:
Gu Shen An Tai Yin (固腎安胎飲) for stabilizing pregnancies.

Formula for snoring in the elderly (老年打鼾).

Treatment of bleeding disorders: Make zhu ma (苧麻, including roots, stems, leaves) into pill form. Each pill is equivalent to 10 g of zhu ma raw herb. Take 4–8 pills per dose, 3–4 times a day. Indications: gastrointestinal bleeding of unknown pathogens, bleeding ulcer, and pulmonary hemoptysis.

For treatment of vaginal bleeding: zhu ma gen (苧麻根, ramie root) 150 g, ai gen (艾根, mugwort root) 100 g, pig kidneys 1 pair (chopped), sweet rice wine 50 c.c., small amount of salt. Prepare as a decoction; take orally. One dose per day. Drink the broth and eat the meat.
Contraindications:
Whole plant and seeds contain hydrocyanic acid.

From Ben Cao Zheng Yi (《本草正義》): Being cold and slippery (既寒且滑), it is not suitable for cases of fetal movement; the root directs downward and is especially contraindicated in pregnancy (尤為妊娠禁品).
Research:
Bleeding disorders treated with zhu ma pills (including roots, stems, leaves): each pill equivalent to 10 g raw herb; dose 4–8 pills, 3–4 times daily. Reported outcomes: bleeding periods were shortened and the amount of bleeding decreased. [1]

Treatment of vaginal bleeding: zhu ma gen 150 g, ai gen 100 g, pig kidneys 1 pair (chopped), sweet rice wine 50 c.c., small amount of salt; decoction taken orally once daily. Total 83 cases: 64 cases due to insertion of birth control rings, 62 effective; 19 cases due to abortions, all effective. Total effectiveness 97.6%. [2]
Notes:
Actions and indications citing Zhong Hua Ben Cao (《中華本草》).

Present-day application: Today, it is mainly substituted with stems. The stems can be repeatedly harvested up to 15 times a year. Using the stems to substitute the roots can greatly lower the cost for herb farmers.

Classic treatises:
1) Ben Cao Jing Shu (《本草經疏》): Zhu gen is used in childhood chidan because its cold nature can cool the blood; soaking ramie juice to treat thirst is due to its heat-removing function. Ri Hua Zi uses it to treat heat in the Heart and diaphragm, leakage of fetus with bleeding, vexation before and after childbirth, epidemic febrile diseases with heat, great thirst with mania, and for arrow poison, snake and insect bites, all due to its cold nature that can resolve heat and cool the blood.
2) Ben Cao Shu (《本草述》): Zhu gen, according to Danxi, greatly tonifies Yin and simultaneously moves congealed blood; sweet-cold medicinals can drain fire. This substance stops bleeding strangury, treats erysipelas; it may enter the blood aspect and drain heat. It is especially effective for calming the fetus and treating leakage of blood, thus its functions of supplementing Yin and activating blood are evident, not merely draining heat.
3) Ben Cao Zheng Yi (《本草正義》): Bai zhu (white ramie) is cold; ancient formulas often state it treats urinary obstruction, five types of strangury with heat binding, thus it has the power to drain heat and free strangury, hence Ri Hua Ben Cao calls it sweet, cold, and slippery. Modern practitioners tend to use it to calm the fetus, but being both cold and slippery it is not suitable for fetal movement; the root directs downward and is contraindicated in pregnancy. Surveying medical texts, only Mei Shi Ji Yan Fang uses it for fetal movement with sudden discharge of yellow fluid; otherwise rarely seen. Danxi also says it moves congealed blood, which conflicts with fetal movement, so it should not be used as a routine fetus-calming drug.

External use: sprains and bruises from injuries (跌打瘀傷)
External use: joint sprain (關節扭傷)
Medical Function: Astringent to the intestine to relieve diarrhea (澀腸止瀉).
Warms the middle and moves Qi (溫中行氣).
Improves digestion and appetite (有增進食慾﹐促進消化作用).
Samples of Formulae:
Rou dou kou wine extract (external): soak the outer wrapping of the seeds (seed outer coat/aril) in rice wine of high alcohol content (three-times distilled rice wine). Let sit at room temperature for about one month. Usage: massage onto areas with sprains and bruises from injuries. Source: family formula of editor.
Si shen wan (四神丸).
Contraindications:
Do not use for diarrhea due to damp-heat infection or food poisoning. Avoid during pregnancy. Contraindicated in hemorrhoids and gum infections (牙周炎).
Toxicity: Large dosage can cause death. Ingesting 7.6 g has been reported to cause dizziness and stupor. Reported manifestations of overdose include dilated pupils, coma, and convulsions.
Notes: Editor note: The dry seeds of rou dou kou used in medicine or as a cooking spice are more toxic than the flesh (meat) of the fruit. In production areas, the pickled fruit are eaten as a snack; after pickling with salt or sugar or vinegar, the toxicity is less.

Name: yan huang lian
Botanical: C. thalictrifolia Franch. non Jameson ex Regel

Maladies Treated: Hepatitis
Mouth and tongue sores (口舌糜爛)
Fire eye (inflammation in the eyes, 火眼)
目翳 (cataracts)
Dysentery (痢疾)
Diarrhea (腹瀉)
Stomach ache (腹痛)
Bleeding hemorrhoids (痔瘡出血)
Dosage:
Oral: decoction 3–15 g.
External application: appropriate amount; grind to powder and apply to affected area.
Samples of Formulae: For acute stomach ache: yan huang lian (Root of Meadowrue Corydalis) 6 g, eat raw.
Contraindications:
No toxicity document available as of this writing.
Beware of counterfeit herb.
Research:
In an experiment with ducks: extract of yan huang liang on liver injury caused by hepatitis B virus has a significant protective effect.
Conclusions: the extract of yan huang lian has a significant effect in the anti-duck hepatitis B virus in vivo.
Notes:
Supply is limited, mainly collected from the wild. Although cultivation has been successful, the yield is very low; herb stores do not generally carry this herb. Since the price has risen to nearly a thousand yuans per kilogram, there are many counterfeit products in the market. The herb is being used by residents and local herb doctors in the producing areas.

Identification (鑒別):
(1) Leaves, stems, and roots of genuine yan huang lian are bitter; some counterfeits have leaves and stems without bitterness.
(2) Dried genuine yan huang lian is yellow-brown; most counterfeits are light green or grass green.
(3) In genuine material, the leaf blade base and petiole are not connected; in counterfeits, the leaf base is broad and connected.
(4) Genuine leaf blades are 1–4-lobed; counterfeits have margins with more than 4 lobes.
(5) Genuine leaves and stems are glabrous (no hairs); some counterfeits have hairs on leaves and stems.
(6) The root cross-section of genuine material is dense and smooth; the pith shows a lattice-like (井字形) light yellow pattern. Counterfeits have loose texture and lack the lattice pith pattern.
References: [2] Zhong Hua Ben Cao 中華本草

Name: yu gan zi
餘甘子
Other name: an mo luo jia guo 庵摩落迦果
Pronunciation in Japanese: anmaroku (庵摩勒) (Sanskrit origin; used in old Chinese medical text)

Maladies Treated: influenza with fever
cough
pain in throat
diphtheria
thirst and irritably hot
hypertension
deficiency of vitamin C
asthma
Medical Function: Ridding of infection and soothing the pharynx, promoting saliva and quenching thirst.
Clears heat and benefits the throat (清熱利咽).
Moistens the Lung and transforms phlegm (潤肺化痰).
Engenders fluids and stops thirst (生津止渴).
Dosage: Taking orally: in decoction 15-30g; or use fresh herb to make juice.
Samples of Formulae:
For influenza with fever, cough, pain in throat, dry mouth and irritable thirst, deficiency of vitamin C: use fresh fructus Phyllanthi (yu gan zi; emblic leafflower fruit) 10–30 pieces. Make into decoction and take orally. (Source: Commonly Used Chinese Herb Booklet by Guangzhou Army)

For diphtheria: fructus Phyllanthi (yu gan zi; emblic leafflower fruit) 500 g, Xuan Shen (Scrophularia root) 30 g, Gan Cao (Licorice root) 30 g. Soak all herbs in cool boiled drinking water till frost develops. Spread the frost on cotton paper and dry under the sun. Add Long Dan Cao powder (Chinese gentian) 6 g, Bing Pian (Borneol) 1.5 g, Bai Guo powder (Ginkgo seed) 15 g. Blow the powder into the throat.

For asthma: fructus Phyllanthi (yu gan zi; emblic leafflower fruit) 21 pieces. First boil pig lung and heart. Discard the bubble floating on the decoction. Add fructus Phyllanthi (yu gan zi). Make into soup. Take orally.
Contraindications: Use with care in cases of spleen deficient.
Research: The ascorbic acid (vitamin C) of this fruit is very stable because of the protective effect of the tannin acid of the fruit. [1]
